frame.if_detail: Add an 𝐢𝐟 conditional statement at the frame cursor.
frame.import_detail: Add an 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭 statement at the frame cursor.
frame.elif_detail: Add an 𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐟 (else if) conditional statement at the frame cursor.
frame.else_detail: Add an 𝐞𝐥𝐬𝐞 conditional statement at the frame cursor.
frame.for_detail: Add a 𝐟𝐨𝐫 loop at the frame cursor.
frame.funcdef_detail: Add a function definition at the frame cursor.
frame.fromimport_detail: Add a 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦...𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭 statement at the frame cursor.
frame.while_detail: Add a 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐞 loop at the frame cursor.
frame.break_detail: Add a 𝐛𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐤 statement at the frame cursor
frame.continue_detail: Add a 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐮𝐞 statement at the frame cursor.
frame.varassign_detail: Add a variable assignment at the frame cursor.
frame.funccall_detail: Add a function call at the frame cursor.
frame.blank_detail: Add a blank frame at the frame cursor.
frame.return_detail: Add a 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 statement at the frame cursor.
frame.comment_detail: Add a comment at the frame cursor.
frame.try_detail: Add a 𝐭𝐫𝐲 statement at the frame cursor.
frame.raise_detail: Add a 𝐫𝐚𝐢𝐬𝐞 statement at the frame cursor.
frame.except_detail: Add an 𝐞𝐱𝐜𝐞𝐩𝐭 statement at the frame cursor.
frame.finally_detail: Add a 𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 statement at the frame cursor.
frame.with_detail: Add a 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 statement at the frame cursor.
frame.global_detail: Add a 𝐠𝐥𝐨𝐛𝐚𝐥 statement at the frame cursor. This keyword allows to modify a variable 𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙𝑙𝑦, from inside a function.

messageBannerMessage.deleteLargeCode: You just deleted a large piece of code. If you didn't mean to, you can:
messageBannerMessage.uploadFailureMicrobit: Upload to micro:bit failed with error "{errorMsg}"
messageBannerMessage.noUndo: There is no undo action avaialble.
messageBannerMessage.noRedo: There is no redo action available.
messageBannerMessage.uploadEditorFileError: Something wrong happened during editor file upload: {errorMsg}. Your code has not changed.
messageBannerMessage.uploadEditorFileNotSupported: This file format is not supported. Expected file extension: {list}. Your code has not changed.
messageBannerMessage.uploadEditorFileSuccess: The editor file upload is successful. Your code has been loaded.
messageBannerMessage.forbiddenFrameMove: The selected frame(s) cannot be moved because it results in illegal code.
messageBannerMessage.forbiddenFramePaste: The selected frame(s) cannot be pasted because it results in illegal code.
messageBannerMessage.functionFrameCantDelete: A function definition frame cannot be deleted from this caret position when content is not empty.
messageBannerMessage.gdriveConnectToSaveFailed: The connection to Google Drive has been lost. The synchronisation with Google Drive is stopped, latest changes may not have been saved.
messageBannerMessage.gdriveCantCreateStrypeFolder: Strype could not create a default "Strype" folder in Google Drive.
messageBannerMessage.wrongPythonStructCopied: cannot paste else/elif/except/finally and further content in one paste
messageBannerMessage.incompatiblePythonStrypeSection: the copied Python code cannot be pasted in the current Strype section

appMenu.loadProjectTooltip: Open project from this device or from Google Drive

apidiscovery.v2InfoMsg: This is only valid for the micro:bit board v2.

microbitAPI.led_doc: The 5x5 LED display of the micro:bit.
microbitAPI.ledScroll_doc: Scrolls text value horizontally on the display.
microbitAPI.ledScroll_extradoc:
If value is an integer or float it is first converted to a string using str().
The delay parameter controls how fast the text is scrolling (150 by default).
If wait is True (default value), this function will block until the animation is finished, otherwise the animation will happen in the background.
If loop is True (False by default), the animation will repeat forever.
If monospace is True (False by default), the characters will all take up 5 pixel-columns in width, otherwise there will be exactly 1 blank pixel-column between each character as they scroll.
Note that the wait, loop and monospace arguments must be specified using their keyword.
microbitAPI.ledShowIm_doc: Displays the image passed as parameter.
microbitAPI.ledShowImTxt_label: Display a text or an image
microbitAPI.ledShowImTxt_doc: If value is a string, float or integer, displays letters/digits in sequence. Otherwise, if value is an iterable sequence of images, displays these images in sequence.
microbitAPI.ledShowImTxt_extradoc:
Each letter, digit or image is shown with delay milliseconds between them (400 by default).
If wait is True (default value), this function will block until the animation is finished, otherwise the animation will happen in the background.
If loop is True (False by default), the animation will repeat forever.
If clear is True (False by default), the display will be cleared after the iterable has finished.
Note that the wait, loop and clear arguments must be specified using their keyword.
microbitAPI.ledGetPix_doc: Returns the brightness of the LED at column x and row y as an integer between 0 (off) and 9 (bright).
microbitAPI.ledSetPix_doc: Sets the brightness of the LED at column x and row y to value, which has to be an integer between 0 and 9.
microbitAPI.ledClear_doc: Sets the brightness of all LEDs to 0 (off).
microbitAPI.ledOff_extradoc: Use off() to turn off the display; allowing you to re-use the GPIO pins associated with the display for other purposes.
microbitAPI.ledIsOn_label: Check if the display is turned on
microbitAPI.ledIsOn_doc: Returns True if the display is on, otherwise returns False.
microbitAPI.ledReadLight_label: Get the light level on the display
microbitAPI.ledReadLight_doc: Returns the amount of light falling on the display as an integer between 0 and 255 representing the light level, with larger meaning more light.
microbitAPI.ImgStr_label: Create an image (from a text value)
microbitAPI.ImgStr_doc:
The text value has to consist of digits 0-9 arranged into lines, describing the image, for example:
image = Image("90009:09090:00900:09090:90009")
will create a 5×5 image of an X. The end of a line is indicated by a colon. It’s also possible to use a newline ( ) to indicate the end of a line like this:
image = Image("90009 09090 00900 09090 90009")
microbitAPI.ImgParam_doc:
This other form creates an empty image with width columns and height rows. Optionally buffer can be an array of width x height integers in range 0-9 to initialize the image:
Image(2, 2, b'\x08\x08\x08\x08')
or:
Image(2, 2, bytearray([9,9,9,9]))
Will create a 2 x 2 pixel image at full brightness.
microbitAPI.ImgBuiltin_doc: All the built-in images provided by micro:bit
microbitAPI.ImgClocks_doc: A collection of images containing all the clock images.
microbitAPI.ImgArrows_doc: A collection of images containing all the arrow images.
microbitAPI.ImgW_doc: Returns the number of columns in the image.
microbitAPI.ImgH_doc: Returns the numbers of rows in the image
microbitAPI.ImgSetPix_label: Set the brightness value of a pixel in the image
microbitAPI.ImgSetPix_doc: Sets the brightness of the pixel at column x and row y to the value, which has to be between 0 (dark) and 9 (bright). This method will raise an exception when called on any of the built-in read-only images, like Image.HEART.
microbitAPI.ImgGetPix_label: Get the brightness value of a pixel in the image
microbitAPI.ImgGetPix_doc: Returns the brightness of pixel at column x and row y as an integer between 0 and 9.
microbitAPI.ImgCpy_doc: Returns an exact copy of the image.
microbitAPI.imgInv_doc: Returns a new image by inverting the brightness of the pixels in the source image.
microbitAPI.ImgLeft_doc: Returns a new image created by shifting the picture left by n columns.
microbitAPI.ImgRight_doc: Returns a new image created by shifting the picture right by n columns
microbitAPI.ImgUp_doc: Returns a new image created by shifting the picture up by n rows.
microbitAPI.imgDown_doc: Returns a new image created by shifting the picture down by n rows.
microbitAPI.ImgCrop_doc: Returns a new image by cropping the picture to a width of w and a height of h, starting with the pixel at column x and row y.
microbitAPI.ImgFill_doc: Sets the brightness of all the pixels in the image to the value, which has to be between 0 (dark) and 9 (bright). This method will raise an exception when called on any of the built-in read-only images, like Image.HEART.
microbitAPI.button_doc: There are two buttons on the board, called button_a (left button) and button_b (right button). The example here are for button_a, but they are valid for button_b as well. You may replace button_a by button_b in your code.
microbitAPI.buttonIsPress_label: Know if a button is pressed
microbitAPI.buttonIsPress_doc: Returns True if the specified button is currently being held down, and False otherwise.
microbitAPI.buttonWasPress_label: Know if a button was pressed
microbitAPI.buttonWasPress_doc: Returns True or False to indicate if the button was pressed (went from up to down) since the device started or the last time this method was called. Calling this method will clear the press state so that the button must be pressed again before this method will return True again.
microbitAPI.buttonGetPress_label: Get the number of button presses
microbitAPI.buttonGetPress_doc: Returns the running total of button presses, and resets this total to zero before returning.
microbitAPI.sounds_doc: All the built-in sounds provided by micro:bit. (Note: sounds are part of the Sound module)
microbitAPI.audio_doc: This module allows you play sounds from a speaker attached to micro:bit. In order to use the audio module you will need to provide a sound source.
microbitAPI.audio_extradoc: A sound source is an iterable (sequence, like list or tuple, or a generator) of frames, each of 32 samples. The audio modules plays samples at the rate of 7812.5 samples per second, which means that it can reproduce frequencies up to 3.9kHz.
microbitAPI.audioPlay_doc:
Plays the source to completion.
source is an iterable, each element of which must be an AudioFrame.
microbitAPI.audioPlay_extradoc:
If wait is True (default value), this function will block until the source is exhausted.
pin specifies which pin the speaker is connected to (pin0 by default).
return_pin specifies a differential pin to connect to the speaker instead of ground (None by default) - ignored for v2.
microbitAPI.audioFrame_label: Get the audio frame object containing the audio samples
microbitAPI.audioFrame_doc:
An AudioFrame object is a list of 32 samples each of which is a signed byte (whole number between -128 and 127).
It takes just over 4 ms to play a single frame.
microbitAPI.mic_doc: This object lets you access the built-in microphone available on the micro:bit V2. It can be used to respond to sound. The microphone input is located on the front of the board alongside a microphone activity LED, which is lit when the microphone is in use.
microbitAPI.currSoundEvent_doc: Returns the name of the last recorded sound event, SoundEvent('loud') or SoundEvent('quiet').
microbitAPI.wasSoundEvent_label: Check if a Sound event happened once
microbitAPI.wasSoundEvent_doc: Checks if the Sound event, such as SoundEvent.LOUD or SoundEvent.QUIET, was heard at least once since the last call. It returns True if so, False if not, and clears the sound event history.
microbitAPI.isSoundEvent_label: Check if a Sound event happened last
microbitAPI.isSoundEvent_doc: Checks if the Sound event, such as SoundEvent.LOUD or SoundEvent.QUIET, is the most recent since the last call. It returns True if so, False if not. It does not clear the sound event history.
microbitAPI.soundEvents_doc: Returns a tuple of the event history. The most recent is listed last. It also clears the sound event history before returning.
microbitAPI.soundEvThres_doc: Associate the threshold level value in the range 0-255 to a given Sound event. For example, set_threshold(SoundEvent.LOUD, 250) will only trigger if the sound is very loud (>= 250).
microbitAPI.soundLevel_doc: Returns a representation of the sound pressure level in the range 0 to 255.
microbitAPI.acc_doc: This object gives you access to the on-board accelerometer.
microbitAPI.acc_extradoc:
The accelerometer also provides convenience functions for detecting gestures. The recognised gestures are: up, down, left, right, face up, face down, freefall, 3g, 6g, 8g, shake.
By default MicroPython sets the accelerometer range to +/- 2g, changing the accelerometer range is currently not possible in MicroPython. The accelerometer returns a value in the range 0..1024 for each axis, which is then scaled accordingly.
microbitAPI.accGest_doc: Returns the name of the current gesture (one these values: up, down, left, right, face up, face down, freefall, 3g, 6g, 8g, shake).
microbitAPI.accXYZ_doc: Gets the acceleration measurements in all axes at once, as a three-element tuple of integers ordered as X, Y, Z. By default the accelerometer is configured with a range of +/- 2g, and so X, Y, and Z will be within the range of +/-2000mg.
microbitAPI.accX_doc: Gets the acceleration measurement in the X axis, as a positive or negative integer, depending on the direction. The measurement is given in milli-g. By default the accelerometer is configured with a range of +/- 2g, and so this method will return within the range of +/- 2000mg.
microbitAPI.accY_doc: Get the acceleration measurement in the Y axis, as a positive or negative integer, depending on the direction. The measurement is given in milli-g. By default the accelerometer is configured with a range of +/- 2g, and so this method will return within the range of +/- 2000mg.
microbitAPI.accZ_doc: Gets the acceleration measurement in the Z axis, as a positive or negative integer, depending on the direction. The measurement is given in milli-g. By default the accelerometer is configured with a range of +/- 2g, and so this method will return within the range of +/- 2000mg.
microbitAPI.comp_doc: This module lets you access the built-in electronic compass. Before using, the compass should be calibrated, otherwise the readings may be wrong.
microbitAPI.compHead_doc: Gives the compass heading, calculated from the above readings, as an integer in the range from 0 to 360, representing the angle in degrees, clockwise, with north as 0.
microbitAPI.compIsCalib_label: Know if the compass is calibrated
microbitAPI.compIsCalib_doc: Returns True if the compass has been successfully calibrated, and returns False otherwise.
microbitAPI.compCalib_doc: Starts the calibration process. An instructive message will be scrolled to the user after which they will need to rotate the device in order to draw a circle on the LED display.
microbitAPI.compClear_doc: Undoes the calibration, making the compass uncalibrated again.
microbitAPI.compGetX_label: Get X axis magnetic field value
microbitAPI.compGetX_doc: Gives the reading of the magnetic field strength on the X axis in nano tesla, as a positive or negative integer, depending on the direction of the field.
microbitAPI.compGetY_label: Get Y axis magnetic field value
microbitAPI.compGetY_doc: Gives the reading of the magnetic field strength on the Y axis in nano tesla, as a positive or negative integer, depending on the direction of the field.
microbitAPI.compGetZ_label: Get Z axis magnetic field value
microbitAPI.compGetZ_doc: Gives the reading of the magnetic field strength on the Z axis in nano tesla, as a positive or negative integer, depending on the direction of the field.
microbitAPI.compGetField_doc: Returns an integer indication of the magnitude of the magnetic field around the device in nano tesla.
microbitAPI.music_doc: You can use the music module to play simple tunes, provided that you connect a speaker to your board (for micro:bit v1).
microbitAPI.musicBuiltin_doc: All the built-in melodies provided by micro:bit
microbitAPI.music1_doc: The opening to Beethoven’s 5th Symphony in C minor.
microbitAPI.music2_doc: The opening fragment of Scott Joplin’s Ragtime classic "The Entertainer".
microbitAPI.music3_doc: The opening of the first Prelude in C Major of J.S.Bach’s 48 Preludes and Fugues.
microbitAPI.music4_doc: The "Ode to Joy" theme from Beethoven’s 9th Symphony in D minor.
microbitAPI.music5_doc: The Nyan Cat theme (http://www.nyan.cat/). The composer is unknown. This is fair use for educational porpoises (as they say in New York).
microbitAPI.music6_doc: Something that sounds like a mobile phone ringtone. To be used to indicate an incoming message.
microbitAPI.music7_doc: A funky bass line for secret agents and criminal masterminds.
microbitAPI.music9_doc: "Happy Birthday to You…" for copyright status see: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-34332853.
microbitAPI.music10_doc: The bridal chorus from Wagner’s opera "Lohengrin".
microbitAPI.music11_doc: The “funeral march” otherwise known as Frédéric Chopin’s Piano Sonata No. 2 in B♭ minor, Op. 35.
microbitAPI.music12_doc: A fun fragment that signifies a joke has been made.
microbitAPI.music13_doc: John Philip Sousa’s march "Liberty Bell" aka, the theme for "Monty Python’s Flying Circus" (after which the Python programming language is named).
microbitAPI.music14_doc: Silent movie era entrance of a baddy.
microbitAPI.music16_doc: A short signal to indicate something has happened.
microbitAPI.music18_doc: For use in a game, indicating upward movement.
microbitAPI.music19_doc: For use in a game, indicating downward movement.
microbitAPI.music20_doc: A fanfare to indicate an achievement unlocked.
microbitAPI.music21_doc: A sad fanfare to indicate an achievement lost.
microbitAPI.musicPlay_doc: Plays music containing the musical notation defined in the online documentation.
microbitAPI.musicPlay_extradoc:
If music is a string it is expected to be a single note such as 'c1:4'.
If music is specified as a list of notes (as defined in the section on the musical DSL, see the online documentation) then they are played one after the other to perform a melody.
In both cases, the duration and octave values are reset to their defaults (4, 120) before the music (whatever it may be) is played.
An optional argument to specify the output pin (pin) can be used to override the default of microbit.pin0.
If wait is set to True (default value), this function is blocking.
If loop is set to True (False by default), the tune repeats until stop is called or the blocking call is interrupted.
microbitAPI.musicSetTempo_doc:
Sets the approximate tempo for playback.
A number of ticks (expressed as an integer) constitute a beat. Each beat is to be played at a certain frequency per minute (expressed as the more familiar bpm - beats per minute - also as an integer).
microbitAPI.musicSetTempo_extradoc:
Suggested default values allow the following useful behaviour:
music.set_tempo() - reset the tempo to default of ticks = 4, bpm = 120
music.set_tempo(ticks=8) - change the "definition" of a beat
music.set_tempo(bpm=180) - just change the tempo
To work out the length of a tick in milliseconds is very simple arithmetic: 60000/bpm/ticks_per_beat . For the default values that’s 60000/120/4 = 125 milliseconds or 1 beat = 500 milliseconds.
microbitAPI.musicGetTempo_doc: Gets the current tempo as a tuple of integers: (ticks, bpm).
microbitAPI.musicStop_extradoc: Stops all music playback on a given pin, eg. music.stop(pin1). If no pin is given, eg. music.stop(), pin0 is assumed.
microbitAPI.musicPitch_doc: Plays a pitch at the integer frequency.
microbitAPI.musicPitch_extradoc:
The frequency can be played given a specified number of milliseconds. For example, if the frequency is set to 440 and the length (duration) to 1000 then we hear a standard concert A for one second.
Note that you can only play one pitch on one pin at any one time.
If wait is set to True, this function is blocking.
If duration is negative (default value) the pitch is played continuously until either the blocking call is interrupted or, in the case of a background call, a new frequency is set or stop is called.
microbitAPI.musicReset_doc:
Resets the state of the following attributes in the following way:
ticks = 4
bpm = 120
duration = 4
octave = 4
microbitAPI.pin_doc: The pins are your board’s way to communicate with external devices connected to it.
microbitAPI.pin_extradoc:
There are 19 pins for your disposal, numbered 0-16 and 19-20. Pins 17 and 18 are not available. The pins are of 3 types: digital, analog or touch. Analog pins are used for numerical values between 0 and 1023. Digital pins are used for binary values (0 or 1). Touch pins are used for boolean values indicating if the pin is touched with a finger. Note that analog pins gets the functionalities of the digital pins too, and that touch pins get the functionalities of analog and digital functionalities too.
For micro:bit V2, there are 2 other pins that you can use: pin_logo and pin_speaker. Also, a few more methods are available for getting the pin mode, setting the touch mode etc. See the online documentation for more details.
microbitAPI.pinDig_doc: The digital pins are pins 5 to 9, 11 to 16 and 19 to 20. The example here are for pin 5, but they are valid for other pins as well. You may replace pin5 by pin6, for example, in your code.
microbitAPI.pinDigR_doc: Returns 1 if the pin is high, and 0 if it’s low.
microbitAPI.pintDigW_doc: Sets the pin to high if value is 1, or to low, if it is 0.
microbitAPI.pinAna_doc: The analog pins are pins 3, 4 and 10. The example here are for pin 3, but they are valid for other pins as well. You may replace pin3 by pin4, for example, in your code.
microbitAPI.pinAnaR_doc: Reads the voltage applied to the pin, and return it as an integer between 0 (meaning 0V) and 1023 (meaning 3.3V).
microbitAPI.pinAnaW_doc: Outputs a PWM signal on the pin, with the duty cycle proportional to the provided value. The value may be either an integer or a floating point number between 0 (0% duty cycle) and 1023 (100% duty).
microbitAPI.pinAnaTMls_doc: Sets the period of the PWM signal being output to period in milliseconds. The minimum valid value is 1ms.
microbitAPI.pinAnaTMcs_doc: Sets the period of the PWM signal being output to period in microseconds. The minimum valid value is 256µs.
microbitAPI.pinAnaRD_doc: Returns 1 if the pin is high, and 0 if it’s low.
microbitAPI.pinAnaWD_doc: Sets the pin to high if value is 1, or to low, if it is 0.
microbitAPI.pinTou_doc: The touch pins are pins 0 to 2. The example here are for pin 0, but they are valid for other pins as well. You may replace pin0 by pin1, for example, in your code.
microbitAPI.pinTouR_label: Know if the pin is touched
microbitAPI.pinTouR_doc: Returns True if the pin is being touched with a finger, otherwise return False.
microbitAPI.pinTouR_extradoc: This test is done by measuring how much resistance there is between the pin and ground. A low resistance gives a reading of True. To get a reliable reading using a finger you may need to touch the ground pin with another part of your body, for example your other hand.
microbitAPI.pinTouRA_doc: Reads the voltage applied to the pin, and return it as an integer between 0 (meaning 0V) and 1023 (meaning 3.3V).
microbitAPI.pinTouWA_doc: Outputs a PWM signal on the pin, with the duty cycle proportional to the provided value. The value may be either an integer or a floating point number between 0 (0% duty cycle) and 1023 (100% duty).
microbitAPI.pinTouTMls_doc: Sets the period of the PWM signal being output to period in milliseconds. The minimum valid value is 1ms.
microbitAPI.pinTouTMcs_doc: Sets the period of the PWM signal being output to period in microseconds. The minimum valid value is 256µs.
microbitAPI.pinTouRD_doc: Returns 1 if the pin is high, and 0 if it’s low.
microbitAPI.pintTouWD_doc: Sets the pin to high if value is 1, or to low, if it is 0.
microbitAPI.speech_doc:
WARNING! This is still work in progress.
The quality of the speech is not great, merely "good enough". Given the constraints of the device you may encounter memory errors and / or unexpected extra sounds during playback. This module makes microbit talk, sing and make other speech like sounds provided that you connect a speaker to your board as shown in this page. The speech synthesiser can produce around 2.5 seconds worth of sound from up to 255 characters of textual input. To access this module you need to:
import speech
microbitAPI.speechSay_doc: Says the English words in the string words. The result is semi-accurate for English.
microbitAPI.speechSay_extradoc:
Override the optional pitch (64 by default), speed (72 by default), mouth (128 by default) and throat (128 by default) settings to change the timbre (quality) of the voice. This is a short-hand equivalent of: speech.pronounce(speech.translate(words))
Look at the online documentation for a detailed explanation on how to use these parameters.
For micro:bit V2 an optional argument to specify the output pin can be used to override the default of pin0. If we do not want any sound to play out of the pins can use pin=None.
microbitAPI.speechSing_doc: Sings the phonemes contained in the string phonemes.
microbitAPI.speechSing_extradoc:
Override the optional pitch (64 by default), speed (72 by default), mouth (128 by default) and throat (128 by default) settings to change the timbre (quality) of the voice. Look at the online documentation for a detailed explanation on how to use these parameters.
For micro:bit V2 an optional argument to specify the output pin can be used to override the default of pin0. If we do not want any sound to play out of the pins can use pin=None.
microbitAPI.speechT_doc: Given English words in the string words, returns a string containing a best guess at the appropriate phonemes to pronounce.
microbitAPI.speechT_extradoc:
The output is generated from this text to phoneme translation table.
This function should be used to generate a first approximation of phonemes that can be further hand-edited to improve accuracy, inflection and emphasis.
For micro:bit V2 an optional argument to specify the output pin can be used to override the default of pin0. If we do not want any sound to play out of the pins can use pin=None.
microbitAPI.speechP_doc: Pronounces the phonemes in the string phonemes. See this for details of how to use phonemes to finely control the output of the speech synthesiser.
microbitAPI.speechP_extradoc:
Override the optional pitch (64 by default), speed (72 by default), mouth (128 by default) and throat (128 by default) settings to change the timbre (quality) of the voice. Look at the online documentation for a detailed explanation on how to use these parameters.
For micro:bit V2 an optional argument to specify the output pin can be used to override the default of pin0. If we do not want any sound to play out of the pins can use pin=None.
microbitAPI.speaker_doc: The micro:bit V2 has a built-in speaker located on the rear of the board.
microbitAPI.speaker_extradoc: By default sound output will be via the edge connector on pin 0 and the built-in speaker V2. You can connect wired headphones or a speaker to pin 0 and GND on the edge connector to hear the sounds.
microbitAPI.speakerOff_doc: Turns the speaker off. This does not disable sound output to an edge connector pin.
microbitAPI.microbit_doc: Functions of the microbit module to control the board.
microbitAPI.setVol_doc: Sets the output volume (0-255) of the micro:bit speaker and external speaker or headphones connected to the edge connector pins.
microbitAPI.temp_doc: The temperature is returned in degrees Celcius.
microbitAPI.runned_label: Get how long the board has been running
microbitAPI.runned_doc: Return the number of milliseconds since the board was switched on or restarted.
microbitAPI.sleep_doc: Will pause the execution on the micro:bit for n milliseconds.
microbitAPI.panic_doc: Requires restart. Pass in an arbitrary integer <= 255 to indicate a status.

PEA.importTurtle: Import the module 'turtle' in your code to use Turtle Graphics.
